sen.j: 五辻 高仲（いつつじ たかなか、文化 (元号)4年12月22日 (旧暦)（1808年1月19日） - 明治29年（1896年）6月5日）は江戸時代末期（幕末）から明治時代にかけての公卿。
sen.e: Takanaka ITSUTSUJI (January 19, 1808 - June 5, 1897) was a 'kugyo' (a senior court noble of Third Rank and above) who lived in the end of the Edo period (alternatively called the Bakumatsu, meaning the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate) to the Meiji era.

Takanaka ITSUTSUJI (January 19, 1808 - June 5, 1896) was a 'kugyo' (a senior court noble of Third Rank and above) who lived from the end of the Edo period (alternatively called the Bakumatsu, meaning the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate) into the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: era→periodに変更(統一用語集により）1897→1896in the end→from the endto→into
sen.e: Takanaka ITSUTSUJI (January 19, 1808 - June 5, 1896) was a 'kugyo' (a senior court noble of Third Rank and above) who lived from the end of the Edo period (alternatively called the Bakumatsu, meaning the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate) into the Meiji period.

sen.j: 半家 (公家)の五辻家第33代当主。
sen.e: Takanaka was the thirty-third head of the Itsutsuji family which was a 'hanke' ('kuge' court noble of lower rank).
Takanaka was the thirty-third head of the Itsutsuji family which was a 'hanke' ('kuge' court noble of lower rank).
Takanaka was the thirty-third head of the Itsutsuji family which was a 'hanke' ('kuge' court noble of lower rank).
The Itsutsuji's ancestry can be traced back to the Uda-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Uda)
sen.cmt: 「五辻家の祖先は宇多源氏にまで遡ることが出来る」と意訳しました。参考： http://www1.parkcity.ne.jp/sito/k101.html なお、庭田家は五辻家と同祖（宇多源氏）で、五辻家より格上です。ここでは「宇多源氏権大納言庭田重能」とつながる文章と推測出来ますが、ウェブ上でも句点。で区分されていますので、敢えてつなげませんでした。 Web: http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BA%94%E8%BE%BB%E9%AB%98%E4%BB%B2
sen.e: The Itsutsuji's ancestry can be traced back to the Uda-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Uda)
The Itsutsuji's ancestry can be traced back to the Uda-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Uda)

sen.j: 権大納言庭田重能の子。
sen.e: Takanaka's biological father was Gon Dainagon (Provisional Major Counselor) Shigeyoshi NIWATA.
sen.cmt: 後項冒頭の「の子で」を当項に移動しました。 参考「庭田家」： http://www1.parkcity.ne.jp/sito/k99.html
sen.e: Takanaka's biological father was Gon Dainagon (Provisional Major Counselor) Shigeyoshi NIWATA.
Takanaka's biological father was Gon Dainagon (Provisional Major Counselor) Shigeyoshi NIWATA.

sen.j: 従二位非参議五辻豊仲の養子となった。
sen.e: Takanaka was adopted by Toyonaka ITSUTSUJI who was a Junii Hisangi (an advisor at large of Junior Second Rank).
Takanaka was adopted by Toyonaka ITSUTSUJI who was a Junii Hisangi (an advisor at large of Junior Second Rank).
Takanaka was adopted by Toyonaka ITSUTSUJI who was a Junii Hisangi (an advisor at large of Junior Second Rank).

sen.j: 兄に庭田重基、妹に庭田嗣子（仁孝天皇典侍・大奥上臈上座）らがいた。
sen.e: Takanaka had an older brother whose name was Shigemoto NIWATA and a younger sister who was Tsuguko NIWATA (serving as Emperor Ninko's 'naishi no suke' which was an assistant handmaid in the Kokyu palace which was the imperial harem including the empress's residence; and an 'O-oku joro kamiza' which was a top ranking upper-grade lady-in-waiting at the O-oku [literally, the great interior, which was the women's quarters in Edo Castle and was the shogun's harem])
sen.cmt: 「大奥上臈上座」の適訳が見つかりません。「上臈御年寄上座」とも呼ばれるようですが、女中としての最高位の「上臈」の中でもさらに最高位」と判断しました。 典侍（「ないしのすけ」、又は「てんじ」）http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=Km2aAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA821&dq="naishi+no+suke&lr=&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=%22naishi%20no%20suke&f=false 「上臈」http://books.google.com/books?id=Km2aAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA822&dq=churo+heian&lr=#v=onepage&q=joro%20heian&f=false 「大奥」(Ooku, the great interior, the inner chambers, etc.) http://books.google.com/books?lr=&ei=Cz3iS-zlBYnclQTA4JXJCQ&cd=1&hl=ja&as_brr=0&q=Ooku,+shogun&btnG=%E6%9B%B8%E7%B1%8D%E3%81%AE%E6%A4%9C%E7%B4%A2
sen.e: Takanaka had an older brother whose name was Shigemoto NIWATA and a younger sister who was Tsuguko NIWATA (serving as the Emperor Ninko's 'naishi no suke' which was an assistant handmaid in the Kokyu palace which was the imperial harem including the empress's residence; and an 'O-oku joro kamiza' which was a top ranking upper-grade lady-in-waiting at the O-oku [literally, the great interior, which was the women's quarters in Edo Castle and was the shogun's harem])

Takanaka had an older brother whose name was Shigemoto NIWATA and a younger sister who was Tsuguko NIWATA (serving as the Emperor Ninko's 'naishi no suke' which was an assistant handmaid in the Kokyu palace which was the imperial harem including the empress's residence; and an 'O-oku joro kamiza' which was a top ranking upper-grade lady-in-waiting at the O-oku [literally, the great interior, which was the women's quarters in Edo Castle and was the shogun's harem])

sen.j: 正室は山口氏、継室は松山忠義の娘。
sen.e: Takanaka's lawful wife (which was called 'seishitsu' in Japanese) was from the Yamaguchi clan, and his second wife (which was called 'keishitsu' in Japanese) was a daughter of Tadayoshi MATSUYAMA.
Takanaka's lawful wife (which was called 'seishitsu' in Japanese) was from the Yamaguchi clan, and his second wife (which was called 'keishitsu' in Japanese) was a daughter of Tadayoshi MATSUYAMA.
Takanaka's lawful wife (which was called 'seishitsu' in Japanese) was from the Yamaguchi clan, and his second wife (which was called 'keishitsu' in Japanese) was a daughter of Tadayoshi MATSUYAMA.

sen.j: 養子に五辻継仲（大原重成の子）がおり、子に五辻安仲（継仲の養子となる）・西五辻文仲（西五辻家の祖）がいた。
sen.e: Takanaka had an adopted son, Tsugunaka ITSUTSUJI (whose biological father was Shigenari OHARA) and biological sons, Yasunaka ITSUTSUJI (who was adopted by Tsugunaka) and Fuminaka NISHIITSUTSUJI (the founder of the NISHIITSUTSUJI family).

Takanaka had an adopted son, Tsugunaka ITSUTSUJI (whose biological father was Shigenari OHARA) and biological sons, Yasunaka ITSUTSUJI (who was adopted by Tsugunaka) and Fuminaka NISHIITSUTSUJI (the founder of the NISHIITSUTSUJI family).

Takanaka had an adopted son, Tsugunaka ITSUTSUJI (whose biological father was Shigenari OHARA) and biological sons, Yasunaka ITSUTSUJI (who was adopted by Tsugunaka) and Fuminaka NISHIITSUTSUJI (the founder of the NISHIITSUTSUJI family).
Takanaka's official court rank was a shonii hisangi (an advisor at large of Senior Second Rank).
Takanaka's official court rank was shonii hisangi (an advisor at large of Senior Second Rank).
Takanaka's official court rank was shonii hisangi (an advisor at large of Senior Second Rank).

sen.j: 安政5年（1858年）の日米修好通商条約勅許を求める幕府案に反対し、廷臣88人の列参に加わる（廷臣八十八卿列参事件）。
sen.e: Against a shogunal plan of claiming imperial sanction to signing the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan that was to be signed in 1858, Takanaka participated in a sit-in protest staged by 88 courtiers (which is called the 'Teishin hachijuhachi kyo ressan jiken' incident in Japanese.)
sen.cmt: 「日米修好通商条約勅許に反対し」を直訳すると意味が曖昧になりますので、史実に基づいて「日米･･･条約勅許を求める幕府案に反対し」と補足し訳出しました（注：結局、条約は勅許無しで締結されます）。 参考： http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=a72F6i-CGaAC&pg=PA70&dq=imperial+sanction,+1858&as_brr=3&ei=QW3jS-vgOYHilQTCw43GCQ&cd=1#v=onepage&q=88%2C%20imperial%20sanction%2C%201858&f=false
sen.e: Against a shogunal plan of claiming imperial sanction to the signing of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan that was to be signed in 1858, Takanaka participated in a sit-in protest staged by 88 courtiers (which is called the 'Teishin hachijuhachi kyo ressan jiken' incident in Japanese.)

Against a shogunal plan of claiming imperial sanction to the signing of the Treaty of Amity and Commerce between the United States and Japan that was to be signed in 1858, Takanaka participated in a sit-in protest staged by 88 courtiers (which is called the 'Teishin hachijuhachi kyo ressan jiken' incident in Japanese.)

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）に参与・内国事務局権判事に任命され、同2年少弁となる。
sen.e: In 1868 Takanaka was appointed Councilor (which is called 'sanyo' in Japanese) and Assistant Judicial Officer (which is called 'gonhanji' in Japanese) of the Department of Home Affairs (which is called the 'naikoku jimu kyoku), and became a Minor Controller (which is called 'shoben' in Japanese based on the ritsuryo system) in 1869.
sen.cmt: 内国事務局の訳語は家永豊吉氏著書より採用（現在著者名はA.Ireland）： http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=HC45etcj2OcC&pg=PA26&dq=naikoku+jimu&as_brr=0&ei=DnrjS9aMEKq0kATBu5HACQ&cd=7#v=onepage&q=naikoku%20jimu&f=false 「権判事」訳語は刑法事務局の場合しか見つかりませんが、内国事務局権判事に適用出来るかどうか不明です：http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=47yhjgB-XhgC&pg=PA823&dq=gonhanji&as_brr=0&ei=jnnjS57SBI_ulQT_p6TLCQ&cd=2#v=onepage&q=gonhanji&f=false 「少弁」：http://wiki.samurai-archives.com/index.php?title=Ritsuryo cf.「弁官」：http://books.google.com/books?id=BruaJSZmjHcC&pg=PA306&dq=ritsuryo,+benkan&as_brr=0&ei=e4PjS7elLaqUkASTpInSCQ&hl=ja&cd=1#v=onepage&q=ritsuryo%2C%20benkan&f=false
sen.e: In 1868 Takanaka was appointed Councilor (which is called 'sanyo' in Japanese) and Assistant Judicial Officer (which is called 'gonhanji' in Japanese) of the Department of Home Affairs (which is called the 'naikoku jimu kyoku), and became a Minor Controller (which is called 'shoben' in Japanese based on the ritsuryo system) in 1869.

In 1868 Takanaka was appointed Councilor (which is called 'sanyo' in Japanese) and Assistant Judicial Officer (which is called 'gonhanji' in Japanese) of the Department of Home Affairs (which is called the 'naikoku jimu kyoku), and became a Minor Controller (which is called 'shoben' in Japanese based on the ritsuryo system) in 1869.

sen.j: 明治6年積年の神楽奉仕を褒賞され、同年隠居した。
sen.e: In 1873 Takanaka gained kudos for years of his involvement in the kagura (ceremonial Shinto music and dances) service and went into retirement.
In 1873 Takanaka gained kudos for years of his involvement in the kagura (ceremonial Shinto music and dances) service and went into retirement.
In 1873 Takanaka gained kudos for years of his involvement in the kagura (ceremonial Shinto music and dances) service and went into retirement.

sen.j: 明治19年6月5日、80歳で没した。
sen.e: Takanaka died at the age of 80 on June 5, 1886.
Takanaka died at the age of 80 on June 5, 1886.
Takanaka died at the age of 80 on June 5, 1886.
